Ken,
 
That helps alot, thanks. I'll see what I can do with it.
 
Timmy

Kenneth Stanley <kstanley@...> wrote:
Timmy, 

Let me try to explain the idea.  The sensors are like radars.  Each 
one is a pie slice coming out of the robot at a certain angle.  If 
there is an object within that pie slice, the sensor registers it, 
with a higher value for closer distance.  If there are multiple 
objects in the same slice, the sensor adds up their values.  So for 
example, if there are two enemies between 30 and 60 degrees from the 
robot's heading, then the sensor representing the slice between 30 
and 60 degrees will add up the values of the two objects and feed 
that value to the network.  There may be several radars of this 
type, for example, between 0 and 60, 60 and 120, and 120 and 180.  
(Note that's just an example, not meant to be literally used).  The 
robot knows where things are by seeing which sensor is lighting up, 
and thereby knowing within which angle range objects are located.  
Of course, it is possible that several such sensors may light up at 
the same time if there are multiple objects at different angles.

Let me know if this helps.

ken
